column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat|identity
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=The Beast
#Text=I was thirteen .

#Text=It was spring , the barren time in March when you can not be sure if it is really warmer , but you are so desperate for change that you tell yourself the mud at the edge of the sidewalk is different from winter mud and you are sure that the smell of wet soil has suddenly a bit of the scent of summer rains , of grass and drowned earthworms .
#Text=And it has , because it is spring and inside the ground something is stirring .
#Text=I was wearing a yellow linen dress which my mother had picked out and which I therefore disliked although I knew it flattered me .
#Text=My shoes were white and I was concentrating on keeping them out of the mud .
#Text=My father and I were going to mass — my mother did not go ; she was Protestant .
#Text=My father put his hand on top of my hair , his palm on my head , and I could feel the bone of my skull and my skin and his hot palm , so dry and strong .
#Text=When I was a little girl , he did that often , and called me Muscles .
#Text=He had not called me Muscles or put his hand on my head for a long time .

#Text=I could not help arching my back a little , I wanted to push against his hand like a cat but the instinct that comes with being thirteen , the half - understood caution that makes a girl timid , or wild , the shyness told me to just walk .
#Text=I wanted to feel the rough edge of the pocket of his coat against my cheek , but I was too tall .
#Text=I wanted to be seven again , and safe .
#Text=But I still wanted to push against his hand and put my hand in his pocket and steal the leather palmed glove , that secret animal .
#Text=Instead I went into the church , took a Bulletin , dipped my finger in Holy Water and genuflected .
#Text=The inside of the church smelled like damp wood and furniture polish , not alive at all .
#Text=My father took off his coat and draped it over the edge of the pew and when I came back from communion I stole his glove .
#Text=The paper taste of the wafer was still in my mouth and I took a deep breath of the leather .
#Text=It smelled like March .
#Text=We walked back through the school because it was drizzling , my father tall in his navy suit and my shoes going click on the linoleum .
#Text=There were two classes of each grade , starting at the sixth and going down to the first .
#Text=The hall ended in a T and we went left through the gym , walked underneath the bleachers and stood next to the side door , waiting for the rain to stop .
#Text=It was dark under the bleachers .
#Text=My father was a young man , thirty - five , younger because he liked to be outside , to play softball on Saturday and to take my mother and me camping on vacation .
#Text=He stood rocked back on his heels with his coat thrown over his shoulders and his hands in his pockets .
#Text=I thought of bacon and eggs , toast with peach jam out of the jar .
#Text=I was so hungry .
#Text=The space under the bleachers was secret and dark .
#Text=There were things in the shadows ; a metal pail , a mop , rags .
#Text=Next to the door was a tall wrought - iron candle holder — the kind that stood at either end of the altar .
#Text=There was no holder and the end was jagged .
#Text=On the floor was a wrapper from a French Chew .
#Text=They were sold at eighth - grade basketball games on Friday nights .
#Text=The light from the door made the shadows under the bleachers darker , the long space stretched far away .
#Text=I heard the rain and the faint rustle of paper and smelled damp concrete .
#Text=I did not go near my father but kept my hand in my pocket , feeling the soft leather glove .
#Text=There was a rustling on the concrete and the drizzle of soft rain .
#Text=I wondered if anyone ever went back under the bleachers , if there were crickets or mice there .
#Text=The rustling might have been mice .
#Text=I wished the rain would stop .
#Text=I wanted to go home .
#Text=I made noises with my heels but they were too loud so I stopped .
#Text=Something else clicked and I tried to see what it was but could n’t see anything .
#Text=It was n’t as loud as my heels .
#Text=My father cleared his throat , looking out the door .
#Text=I imagined a man down there in the dark , an escaped convict or a madman .
#Text=It had nearly stopped raining .
#Text=In fifteen minutes we would be home and my mother would fry eggs .
#Text=I heard a noise like paper .
#Text=My father heard it , too , but he pretended not to , at least he did n’t turn his head .
#Text=And there was a heavier sound , a rasp , like a box pulled over concrete .
#Text=I looked at my father but he did n’t turn his head .
#Text=I wished he would turn his head .
#Text=There was a click again and the rustle , and I could not think of what it could be .
#Text=I had no explanation for the particular combination of sounds .
#Text=No doubt there was , some two things that happened to be making noises at the same time .
#Text=Once in a fever I heard thousands of birds outside my window and I was terrified that they would fling themselves through the glass and attack me , but it was only the rain on the eaves .
